channel.title: Obscure Music on Tedium: The Dull Side of the Internet.
channel.description: Recent content in Obscure Music on Tedium: The Dull Side of the Internet.

item.title: Hide And Seek
His Name Was Larry
item.description: Editor’s note: Hey all, Ernie here with another piece from David Buck, who wrote his first Tedium piece on outsider icon R. Stevie Moore. Turns out his knowledge of outsider artists goes deep—as you’ll see with today’s piece. Today in Tedium: “I’ve got a camera, loaded with film,” he sang, “I’m gonna take a picture of you.” I became particularly fascinated with the unique vocal stylings of Larry “Wild Man” Fischer after hearing his song “I Got a Camera” on a warm summer day, just before my freshman year of high school.

item.title: Moore R. Stevie Moore
The Man With 400 Albums
Let’s Be Frank
item.description: Behind the Mask: It takes a certain kind of human being to create a persona for yourself, and—by all accounts—Chris Sievey was very much that person. The British musician made his name in the ‘80s with an oddball comic persona named Frank Sidebottom, who was noted for both the giant mask he wore and his ability to rewrite classic pop songs into comic odes about Frank’s hometown, the Manchester suburb of Timperley.

item.title: Bizarre String Theories
item.description: Today in Tedium: Of the many fascinating experiments on the internet these days involving red hot nickel balls, my personal favorite is this one, involving two guitars. This clip, apparently inspired by nickel-ball innovator Matthew Neuland’s uncle, at first attempted to show whether a fiery nickel ball would put the guitar out of tune. Then Neuland used the nickel ball to destroy the strings. It’s far from the first example of someone messing with guitar strings just to see what might happen—in fact, there’s something of a whole subgenre of guitar playing based on the concept of modifying or breaking guitars in unusual ways.

item.title: Trippin' On A Hole In A Paper Heart
item.description: Today in Tedium: As we were putting the finishing touches on last Thursday’s Tedium, a terrible bit of news hit the internet—the death of Scott Weiland, one of the most influential rock vocalists of the last quarter-century. Weiland’s death, for many, was not a surprise, and that fact was touched upon by his former band, Stone Temple Pilots. In 2013, Weiland was kicked out of the band he helped make famous, leading to a lengthy legal battle between the two sides.

item.title: Tape Deck Heart
item.description: Today in Tedium: When’s the big comeback for magnetic tapes coming around, anyway? These days, vinyl is making a serious comeback with the public. Even Taylor Swift is selling a ton of vinyl records these days. But in a world where streaming and optical discs are more common than ever, the magnetic tape—which arguably has as much nostalgic hipster cachet as the vinyl record, and across a variety of formats at that—hasn’t seen nearly as much love.

item.title: A Tale of Creative Destruction
item.description: Today in Tedium: The early Counting Crows hit “Mr. Jones” was a lie. Take that back—the incident was real, and Adam Duritz did hang out with a guy with the last name Jones, but the song’s whole plotline about how they were gonna be happier when they were famous didn’t come to pass. If you go to a Counting Crows show these days, in fact, the lyric is now “we all wanna be big, big stars, yeah, but then we get second thoughts about that.
